oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Apparent Prevalence of Congenital Infections in Calves Born on a Single California Dairy Herd
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Aly, Sharif
Glover, Alexandria
Champagne, John
Pithua, Patrick
Lehenbauer, Terry
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: placenta
in utero
immunoglobulins
leukocytes
pathogens
bovine leukosis virus
nfectious bovine rhinotracheitis
bovine viral diarrhea
Neospora caninum
Leptospira hardjo
Leptospira Pomona
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The placenta in cattle prevents in utero transfer of maternal immunoglobulins and leukocytes to the fetus. The fetal immune system, on the other hand, can be exposed to pathogens that cross the placental barrier and mount an immune response to bovine leukosis virus (BLV), infectious bovine rhinotracheitis (IBR), bovine viral diarrhea (BVD) types 1 and 2, Neospora caninum (NC), Leptospira hardjo (LH), and Leptospira Pomona (LP). The objective of this study was to determine the apparent prevalence of congenital infections to common infectious pathogens in calves.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2011; 186
